articles.headline: With Trump in White House, Some Executives Ask, Why Not Me?
articles.snippet: Boldface names discussed as contenders for the Democratic nomination include Howard Schultz, Robert A. Iger, Marc Benioff, Sheryl Sandberg and Oprah Winfrey.
articles.abstract: Boldface names discussed as contenders for the Democratic nomination include Howard Schultz, Robert A. Iger, Marc Benioff, Sheryl Sandberg and Oprah Winfrey.
articles.lead_paragraph: Having reached the top of a major corporation and amassed a fortune, chief executives often wonder: What’s next?

articles.headline: With Rebels Gone, Colombia Jumps Into the Pot Industry
articles.snippet: The government, which has received billions in American aid to eradicate the drug trade, will license a small number of companies to cultivate medical marijuana.
articles.abstract: The government, which has received billions in American aid to eradicate the drug trade, will license a small number of companies to cultivate medical marijuana.
articles.lead_paragraph: CORINTO, Colombia — For years, Blanca Riveros has had the same routine: After fixing breakfast and taking her son to school, she heads home to a large plastic trash bag filled with marijuana.

articles.headline: South Korea Removes President Park Geun-hye
articles.snippet: The president’s ouster, after months of turmoil over a corruption scandal, is expected to shift the country’s politics to the opposition on the left.
articles.abstract: The president’s ouster, after months of turmoil over a corruption scandal, is expected to shift the country’s politics to the opposition on the left.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — A South Korean court removed the president on Friday, a first in the nation’s history, rattling the delicate balance of relationships across Asia at a particularly tense time.

articles.headline: Are You Middle Class Enough to Deserve a Health Care Tax Break?
articles.snippet: The Republican health care bill sets income parameters that may — or may not — look like a useful benchmark, depending on your perspective.
articles.abstract: The Republican health care bill sets income parameters that may — or may not — look like a useful benchmark, depending on your perspective.
articles.lead_paragraph: Something fascinating happened during the most recent rewrite of the Obamacare repair bill: Its authors tried to define who is middle class enough to be deserving of a big tax handout.

articles.headline: Steady U.S. Job Growth Sets Stage for Fed to Raise Interest Rates
articles.snippet: The economy added 235,000 jobs and unemployment fell to 4.7 percent in the first full month of President Trump’s term, continuing an upturn in the labor market.
articles.abstract: The economy added 235,000 jobs and unemployment fell to 4.7 percent in the first full month of President Trump’s term, continuing an upturn in the labor market.
articles.lead_paragraph: A wave of hiring in February — President Trump’s first full month in office — pointed to a strong foundation for the nation’s economy, providing further evidence for the Federal Reserve that the moment to raise interest rates has come.

articles.headline: Even Before the Wall, Migrants Find the U.S. Forbidding
articles.snippet: A sharp drop in illegal crossings, possibly as a result of President Trump’s immigration policies, is being felt along both sides of the border.
articles.abstract: A sharp drop in illegal crossings, possibly as a result of President Trump’s immigration policies, is being felt along both sides of the border.
articles.lead_paragraph: SONOYTA, Mexico — Reiner Ríos Gómez, who is from Honduras’s capital, Tegucigalpa, lifted his shirt last week to expose a scar about 12 inches long in the middle of his back, where he said a machete hit him as he fled the robbers who were trying to steal his pay: 2,800 lempiras, or about $119, for half a month’s work in construction.
articles.byline: By Fernanda Santos, Kirk Semple and Caitlin Dickerson

articles.headline: ‘Revolution? What Revolution?’ Russia Asks 100 Years Later
articles.snippet: The events of 1917 reshaped the country and the world, but the idea of celebrating an uprising of any sort is unwelcome in the Kremlin.
articles.abstract: The events of 1917 reshaped the country and the world, but the idea of celebrating an uprising of any sort is unwelcome in the Kremlin.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — The Kremlin plans to sit out the centenary of the Russian Revolution.
